results.content:
The course started out great, the history and simple understanding of bloackchain and Ethereum. The JavaScript with remix was fun and easy to understand. Once the coding shifted to Atom while using the terminal, it became fast and confusing. When I tried to follow along, I found myself searching for answers on how to use Atom (installing packages, libraries, etc.), some of the material presented was outdated, and these were too much for me. 

The instructor uses a mac/linux based course, but provides little to no instruction for Windows  users. He explains that people can use whatever JavaScript IDE they want, but since he uses Atom and everything in this course resolves around Atom, the instructor should give step-by-step instructions for all platforms on what exactly he is doing.  

I did not enjoy all the terminal coding to get Atom to work effectively since I came into the course with little experience with it and that made the course so overwhelming that I had to stop wasting my time at this point.

In order to fully understand and complete this course, it seems I have to learn more JavaScript and understand Atom along with command prompt, terminal, and Git.

This course states to be the Complete Developer's Guide, but it is based off an already experienced developer that can use Atom and more advanced terminal instructions. Overall, I had a bad experience with this course because I am not up to the speed of the instructor or understand the functionality of what he is doing. Very much unclear most of the time on what is being said and/or done.

results.content:
I chose to quit learning this course because it uses outdated software (node modules, solidity compiler, Remix IDE). It is quite difficult to learn when your linter is complaining about the compiler version, and when you try to downgrade to the version in these lectures, you find yourself learning solidity programming using well outdated and deprecated syntax, style and approaches. 

The other start I've taken away in this rating is that only after going through 1/5 of the course, you start doing practical things and then stumble at all these linter and versioning issues. Having that much of preflight and side topics might play well for those who want to start from the ground, but for others these lectures could have been made skippable.

Still, I recognize the manner of narration and clean English -- these 2 components are important for comprehension, and you will often find courses offered by non-native English speakers lacking these 2 properties.

Peace.

results.content:
Perfect for beginners to coding in general, but experienced developers may feel a bit put off by the constant repetition of absolute basics and the verbosity of Stephens explanations. 

Stephen pads out his videos too much with double and triple explanations of the same thing, such as reminding us more than once not to misspell address (like really?) which is only one example in a huge array of instances. 

I also feel that the course needs to be updated to reflect the current state of solidity and its surrounding tooling and ecosystem as many concepts in the video are deprecated entirely.

Another negative aspect is that it seems people are mostly complaining that Stephen does not reply to their questions. I believe that if someone has paid up to $200 (it can happen on Udemy) for a course then they should get some level of support.

I will say this, for the price I paid for the course (don't pay any more than $15!) I think it does give a good introduction to the Ethereum world in general, but I would not recommend this course based on my previous statements.

results.content:
Amazing course as always. I feel as though this time around Stephen spent more time and effort elaborating on how React and Semantic UI works relative to the amount of time giving deep thoughtful explanations of what Solidity is doing. It would be nice for Stephen to have revisited the logic in the contract to keep it fresh in our heads yet he chose to spend alot of the time writing out React boilerplate. Using a more intuitive framework like Vue would be nice for future courses pertaining to outside technologies like Solidity would be nice so we don't have to spend 50% of the course writing verbose React code.

Update: After going over the course a second time I'm giving it a 5/5 rating. I still stand by my opinion of Vue over React. Course could have been 2x as fast using Vue with how much time you'd save not typing out React overhead.

results.content:
Hi Everyone!

I passed through different courses and I strongly recommend this one. So far the best to me. I even enjoyed the React / Next part which was totally new to me. But having experienced Truffle and some other means to create Front-End interfaces for your DApp projects, I must say that React makes it really easier.

Thank you Stephen for the very good job! looking forward to listen to you again (I already subscribed to your 'Modern React with Redux' course ;) !
results.content_html:
Hi Everyone!

I passed through different courses and I strongly recommend this one. So far the best to me. I even enjoyed the React / Next part which was totally new to me. But having experienced Truffle and some other means to create Front-End interfaces for your DApp projects, I must say that React makes it really easier.

Thank you Stephen for the very good job! looking forward to listen to you again (I already subscribed to your 'Modern React with Redux' course ;) !

results.content: Great course. I was disappointed to do so much react and front-end but I had to learn it anyway. For the price of the course, the absolute balloon of content you receive is disproportionate. The videos are great for absolute beginners but as someone slightly more intermediate it was boring at times. I will urge students to go x1.25 or x1.5 at times. But the instructor does explain things very solidly and candidly. Great course overall and worth the money and time.

results.content:
Did not give an adequate explanation of the big picture and how all fits together. Links to the white papers do not suffice. While I appreciate its early in the course., I believe an overview graphic would have been useful as opposed to the stay with me approach.

That being said, I believe the pace is somewhat slow in describing what is going on and there is significant redundancy in describing our status at the start and end of every lecture because there is an over-emphasis on keeping lecutres very short. It's okay to present 2 or even 3 concepts in a single lecture - even if it has to be 12-15 minutes.

results.content:
Recommended to anybody interested in Ethereum. The instructor covers everything that you need to know, you can tell he knows his stuff. He shows real world applications, not just theory and shows how it can be related to your own projects. Ethereum is still in it's infancy, but the possibilities are endless. I only recently gotten involved but it really is the internet of the future. Well worth the money to learn about how this tech works and be a part of expanding it's applications.

Side note: He goes at a steady pace but I recommend putting the video speed to 1.25x, I find that comfortably picks up the tempo. I find that to be the case for all Udemy instructor videos though, not just in this particular instance.

Only reason I have not given a full 5 star is that I would have liked some more in depth solidity concepts and may be token standards like ERC20 covered instead of a lot of React JS content. results.content:
The solidity coding sections were excellent and I feel like I was able to pick up a lot in just a couple days. 

However, the react appendix was very frustrating for me as someone who had never used react before and I would encourage someone in that position to lightly skim through it, as many of the unfamiliar errors I took a decent amount of time to troubleshoot didn't end up being relevant in the much easier section 4. That said, I am learning solidity primarily to work directly with contracts and not build an interactive and polished front-end, so this may not apply to everyone. 

I will say that getting back to building simple UI elements to reflect solidity transactions in section 4 was much easier having had the react introduction, so I wouldn't recommend skipping it entirely.
results.content_html:
The solidity coding sections were excellent and I feel like I was able to pick up a lot in just a couple days.

However, the react appendix was very frustrating for me as someone who had never used react before and I would encourage someone in that position to lightly skim through it, as many of the unfamiliar errors I took a decent amount of time to troubleshoot didn't end up being relevant in the much easier section 4. That said, I am learning solidity primarily to work directly with contracts and not build an interactive and polished front-end, so this may not apply to everyone.

I will say that getting back to building simple UI elements to reflect solidity transactions in section 4 was much easier having had the react introduction, so I wouldn't recommend skipping it entirely.

results.content:
Hot topic + brilliant instructor = can't miss!

Stephen's course is an in-depth introduction into the realm of the blockchain and smart contracts, from creating & deploying a contract written in Solidity to putting together a front-end interface to interact with that contract.

Over the span of this course, you'll interact with:
- Remix (an online Solidity IDE & debugger)
- Metamask (an extension that adds an Ethereum wallet to your Chrome browser)
- Web3 (an Ethereum Javascript API)
- React (a thorough introductory section is included in the course)
- NextJS (a framework that supports server-side rendering of multi-page React apps)
- Semantic UI (in the form of its 'smart' React implementation)

Thank you Stephen, looking forward to a follow-up!

results.content: Its April 2021.  I really liked the instruction style, and the way the course was presented. I really wish I would have taken it 3 years ago. Today the content is too dated, the code does not compile without extreme efforts, even when you roll back to old versions of Solidity, Node, Truffle etc..  I am sure there are ways to get the code to work, but I spent some amount of days at it without a lot of success. I believe this course could still have benefit, but the course author needs to step in with content updates, or at the very least provide detailed workarounds for all the tooling incompatibilities.

results.content:
Overall, the course is really really good, kudo to an effort making this extraordinary, exceptional and quality course. I find the author is always provide really good explanations on almost every topic he brings to the course.

Only a minor downside regarding teaching style is that the author keeps saying things like 'the last thing I want to do', 'the last issue we have to fix', 'the last etc. etc.' when it's not the last. Also, anothing that could be improved is that the course could be more concise if not spending time anticipating that students will face the same gotcha as the author, rather instead just be more direct to the point. Anyway, just my two cents.

results.content:
Arguably the best Ethereum & Solidity course available for an extremely cheap price. There is so much content that really evolves in depth along the course. The effort to prepare this valuable course content should actually be highly appreciated.

If you want to get started with smart contracts and solidity, if you like to play with an end-end solution, if you don't mind learning so many technologies along the way like react, next which is so awesome - this course is for you.

At the same time, I would also like to mention that it would have been better if we could work with real account creation on the way with our campaign app without using metamask. The instructor mentioned this along with the course few times, but it's sad that this is not part of the course. And also we didn't see a way to update existing contract code which is already deployed. The path we took as part of this course was just to re-deploy a new contract.

Anyway I cannot give anything other than a 5-star review for this awesome course.

Thanks Stephen
results.content_html:
Arguably the best Ethereum & Solidity course available for an extremely cheap price. There is so much content that really evolves in depth along the course. The effort to prepare this valuable course content should actually be highly appreciated.

If you want to get started with smart contracts and solidity, if you like to play with an end-end solution, if you don't mind learning so many technologies along the way like react, next which is so awesome - this course is for you.

At the same time, I would also like to mention that it would have been better if we could work with real account creation on the way with our campaign app without using metamask. The instructor mentioned this along with the course few times, but it's sad that this is not part of the course. And also we didn't see a way to update existing contract code which is already deployed. The path we took as part of this course was just to re-deploy a new contract.

Anyway I cannot give anything other than a 5-star review for this awesome course.

Thanks Stephen

results.content:
This really is the kind of content you can only love. 

I have a heavy security background with "academic" dev skills (ie: dev is something I know how to do not something I do a lot). 

At first glance during the first chapters, I was slightly set aback by the "light" intro on ethereum/blockchain fundamental concepts. However, I quickly understood that this was for the best! 

This course focuses on making you a developer fully able to implement a complete Ethereum application. And in my opinion, it succeeds 100% in doing so. I went in with only a good understanding of blockchain concepts. A few days later I come out of this course with full confidence that I now have the fundamentals I need to build my own "Ethereum application".

1. I would definitely recommend this course to anyone.
2. I'm already checking other courses available from the same author.

results.content:
Pros: Enunciation very clear, structure is PERFECT. He goes through each point in the flow that students need. I really like the side bar deep dives. They come when right when needed.
Cons: 
1. From time-to-time, a term might be mentioned when talking about the blocks. For instance, when the "mining" topic came up, it would have been good to see the word MINING and a process icon/graphic. Instead, we left that crucial screen without having seen such a crucial term. My first thought is that this was a drawback of not using powerpoint. 
2. All slides are done in a Visio clone (draw.io). It was a no-frills slide deck. True, there were no distractions. But we've grown so accustomed to PowerPoint or even web-page type interaction, seeing slides in "visio" turned into the distraction. Another instance would be that his mouse might accidentally select a shape that had nothing to do with the topic... just distracting.
Overall, I'd say 4.8 so far.

results.content:
95% basic programming knowledge and Javascript. Not for experienced programmers.

This course has 24 hours of lectures, but the blockchain-related content is probably 2 hours. The rest of the course is explaining basic programming concepts like basic types, functions, pointers, hashmaps vs arrays, etc.  And 12 hours is just Javascript. Not recommend if your goal is to learn about smart contracts. Fine if you want to learn "programming"

results.content:
This course provides a full overview on building a full stack ethereum application which is good enough to deploy on production while providing good introduction to blockchain, ethereum, react, web3, ganache, jsx, mocha, metamask and surprisingly TDD.

Great teaching method employed by Stephen which helps you to understand the concepts in depth and also prevents you from making glaring mistakes while building production applications. 

Only Criticism: This is tutorial doesn't use the latest version of solidity, web3, next (Dynamic routing available now and no need of additional next-routes package). Nevertheless, a good challenge to apply your learning.

results.content_html: OK

results.content:
Prior to this course I looked at ethereum posts for weeks and it was such a swamp that nothing made sense (apart from Loom's cryptozombies lessons on solidity). 
So I tried this course as a last resort with very low expectations. 
I would have been happy if the outcome was I just became more proficient with solidity.

My expectations were blown away by this course.
I have learnt more in depth solidity.
But I have also learnt:
- How ethereum connects to the Javascript world via web3
- Remix IDE in depth
- Metamask in depth
- How deterministic wallets work
- How to use the Rinkeby Test network and infura
- How to workaround the solidity gotchas
- How the web3 providers work
- Updated Javascript syntax (ES6)
- How to use node and npm
- How to test using Javascript, node and npm
- How to set up a dev environment using Javascript, node and npm
- Why updated Javascript ES6 and React complement ethereum development  
- How to use the React Library
- How to use next.js and routes to handle multi page applications
- How to use symantic-ui-react to develop a really impressive UI

I walk away from this course with:
- Examples on how integrate the ethereum/solidity back end with a React / next.js front end
- Tools to enable me to build and test my own integrated project


Stephen Grider is an excellent teacher.
He explains every topic on the simplest and clearest possible way so what seemed so complicated and confusing to me 10 days ago now makes sense.

results.content:
Alright then, here is the moment of truth, after so many 'one last thing' and 'big gotchas' I am finally able to complete this course.

Stephen, as you would know, is a perfectionist who gives in-depth explanations, (which sometimes get repetitive and may sound irritating), but it shows his commitment of doing an error free knowledge transfer.

Now coming to the course;  very in-depth. I never knew Ethereum and Solidity in that detail. One thing I found that, this course is fully dependant on MetaMask. I wonder, how to create/transact an Ethereum  blockchain without MetaMask account. Should have a video on that. 

A note here: This course is specifically on learning Ethereum blockchain and Solidity. Please do not expect things like ICO, crypto, creating your own coin etc. in this course.

// Acccounts always exposed
window.web3.eth.sendTransaction({/* ... */});
}
// Non-dapp browsers...
else {

}
}
loadWeb3();

results.content:
Excellent dive into the ethereum world! The Dapps created all along are really helping to grasp the fundamentals. The last one in particular is a blast to develop with the help of Stephen. Well explained, well-paced and very detailed, this course is a amazing start for whom wants to start developping Dapps with Javascript and React. Only bad thing I could maybe tell is the end of the course: it's a bit brutal. I would have like a complete wrapup of the CrowdFunding app with maybe a part for what can be improve and maybe what's next to learn to become better at developping Dapps (but maybe an advanced course is in the pipe ;D).
Overall I highly recommend this course, it's a gem!

results.content:
Practical and deep learning is a key point of Stephen Grider's courses.

I really liked this course and I think it would be really helpful for anybody is going to start learning Ethereum and Solidity. 

There is one topic which is not the instructor faults is about software version. Time to time tools are being updated and the code should be refactored ASAP.

The only topic that I think could be improved is about duplication explanation. Somehow about a peace of code and the reason of coding style, somehow about why we need to learn React during the course and etc. 

By the way, Stephen Grider is a really good and nice teacher. I would try to take other courses of him.

results.content:
Overall the content of this course is great! 

If you already have programming experience you might find the pace pretty brutal though. It's not clear what sections were vital so I ended up watching most videos at 125-150% increase in speed. If you're a beginner programmer you will find many basic and advanced concepts covered.

The course does cover it's objective and I do feel like I have enough base knowledge to start engineering Ethereum projects which is what I was after the most. I will consider Stephen's other courses in the future.

Would recommend to others interested in technology.

results.content:
The course is interesting and informative.
Thank you very much.

However, I regret that the instructor explains a lot about JavaScript, React and Mocha. This is not a course on React or Mocha! The same course for experienced JavaScript programmers with only half of the videos (those on MetaMask, Solidity, Remix, and then just a few words on how to use and test smart contracts with JS and the Web3 API) would have been perfect!

results.content:
The Ethereum/solidity stuff was really good. I liked the time spent on solidity contracts and issues around them as well as interfacing from web applications.

The hubris around the evangelizing of React was not appreciated. It was not necessary for learning how to interface from a web app to Ethereum.  The  multi page web app section was 70 lectures and over 6.5 hours with at least 80% or more of it around pushing React and its ecosystem. Teaching React, next, next-routing and the React Semantic UI in such detail was a waste of time. That stuff should have been put in the React appendix so that we could have moved quicker in building a web app rather than getting bogged down in learning about next routing and looking at Semantic UI component docs. Some lectures were about NOTHING other than styling.

results.content:
The course started out very promising, just what I was looking for and I like the instructor.

The first big problem however was talking a lot about basics and then when we get to the most important part about setting up a development environment to actually work on, it is completely glossed over with no information. I did finally get a development environment set up by doing my own research around the internet. Having some simple step by step instructions could have saved me a lot of time.

The major problem however is that the content/code is so out of date, without enough knowledge it was impossible to get anything working. I eventually gave up and instead read more up to date guides.

I totally understand the problem that the whole ecosystem is changing so rapidly but I think the author could easily provide code updates and the rest of the course would still be relevant.

results.content:
I didn't know anything about blockchains and just a little bit about Ethereum, and within a few of Stephen's videos this scenario has changed a lot more than I thought it would...

The course is quite long and I didn't even finish 1/4 of it by now, but the quality of Stephen's knowledge and his ability to clarify such complicated topics is admirable.  He is a deep connoisseur of this subject; every explanation details not only HOW some stuff works but also WHY it works that way. Here are some of the things I like the most:

- He uses diagrams and images to explain how structures work (which, for me, are simpler than long spoken lectures), and details line codes for better understanding. 
- The lecture's duration is great: not long enough to overload you with information, but not short to the point that a subject cannot be completed within a single video.
- His speech is excellent and very clear, and the automatic transcriptor in the videos is quite accurate.

Honestly, if I had to point anything I don't enjoy about this course, I couldn't. Amazing course, incredible instructor. If you wanna know about Smart Contracts, Solidity and Blockchain, this is YOUR course!

Mr. Grider, what an amazing job you did here! I'm eager to get some more courses from you as soon as I get this done.

results.content: Good introduction for non-programmers. Lacking systematic or structured solidity or pyethereum language training. Not sure if "Using Infura as a [sole] provider, you can reliably send and receive messages to/from the Ethereum blockchain without needing to set up and maintain your own node." https://lnkd.in/d_3-tVD  It seems a security hole, bad software architecture and a single point of failure, also there is no advantage in smart contract verification and audit whatsoever. I would go for the node mantainance option, depending on the costs and risk of the project. If the specific project doesn't have this type of risk concerns, I I guess there is no point in using a decentralized network. Keeping a critical mindset and asking why. https://lnkd.in/dAKtt4C

results.content:
This course is good as it goes through every step, and explains in depth every concept.

Downfall: 

-HIGHLY OUTDATED. The version out now is 5.1, while the instructor still uses 4.17. Lots of concepts are not working/deprecated, and the really cool and useful new features aren't shown... 

-By going so much in depth it can get pretty long and borring, and the instructor tens to emphasize/repeat a tad too much.

-Terrible lack of real-world examples (existing apps..), and of hands on exercises. There is a couple of projects which you build through learning, but there could be a lot more simpler exercises, all along the course, helping to make use of the new learnt stuff.

-Not very interactive. Just a voice with diagrams and coding lines.

To summarize it's really good to see all possible steps (contracts creation, deployment, testing) but there is a terrible lack of practice excercises and the course is totally outdated.

results.content: I think Stephen has provided a simple and understandable pace of learning, particularly because of his careful and detailed approach to teaching. He's called out the key issues that all programmers are expected to face, but he helps beginners like myself with solid diagrams that make sense of what previously felt like a black box. I'm very impressed and grateful for his work.

results.content:
pros - i dont know any thing about coding or any thing and im absolutely blown away at how well he breaks every thing down and every thing seems to flow together and makes sense, his knowledge of this topic is extremely obvious and helps me feel confident in what he is teaching, 

i took this course hoping to get started as a dev building dapps, i have also tried other online learning platforms to learn solidity and dapps and nothing even comes close to how amazing this course is, if i knew how good it was i would have paid $500+ for this 

cons -that being said i realise how much i love and hate block-chain technology and building dapps,  every thing changes so much that ive wasted literal days just trying to figure out how to install and make all of the 500 million packages and modules you need to do this, i found being able to complete the course literally impossible to do as a beginner who dosnt know how to make things work when theyre broken, this is not the instructors fault, he has updates with in the course but i wish i knew how frustrating it is trying to hunt down all the the things i need to try and install and if one thing isnt working then your entire project is broken, so youre forced to use outdated things along side more broken packages ,

again this is not the courses fault, thats why im giving it 5 stars, the course it self is incredible and i stopped following along at lesson 43 cause i was so fed up with every thing and just getting errors and trying to google the errors and none of the "fixes" worked  for me, but im enjoying watching the videos and will finish the course and take notes, i know i will learn a TON regardless, thank you for taking the time to do this course, it has changed my life , im going to be pursuing this and make it work or die trying thanks to you

results.content:
The instructor has a really good knowledge of JavaScript and React but seems that he prepared the very basic of Ethereum just for the course. Repeats over and over again the same concepts. This course could be condensed on 8 or 10 hours.

The examples are good, and well structured, but seems more focused on the React part than in the Ethereum. I understand that some fronted integration with Ethereum is needed, but it spends so much time on things not related with Ethereum.

Is a good starting point, but really far from "The Complete Developer's Guide".

Honestly, I had no previous idea about Ethereum (although a good previous knowledge of JS), so at least I learn just enough to keep learning on my own about ethereum. It wasn't a waste of time, but not worthy enough.

results.content: I have used other Coding udemy classes a lot for the last couple of months. In this course I realized that you can just watch videos and nothing else. The best way you learn is when you do but there is no way to practise what is being teached. Other classes deploy the Jupiter Notebook for Python, so you actually not only watch videos but also answer questions and solve given tasks. Do not get me wrong I am a beginner in Coding in general but this class is not for beginners at all, jumping back and forth between a dozen different appliacations like the authors editor and the terminal gave me a headache already. What editor is it exactly, where do I find it, how do I use it? For pro coders certainly easy stuff however you cannot call this a beginners guide when the author assumes fluent knowledge of the underlying IT architecture. I could not write a single line of code 1 year ago, now I can understand Python code and use Numpy and Panda applications thanks to INTERACTIVE and easy to learn lessons. This course however I leave in a  frustrated state after 10% of the lessons. :-(

results.content: This course not only teaches Solidity and Remix, but goes into great depth around technologies that will interact with Ethereum and Blockchain. I found this incredibly useful and that i can take the knowledge from the course and build a real world application. For this, i feel the course is fantastic value for money. Stephen is a very good tutor. He is easy to understand, and is clearly very knowledgeable in this subject. I highly recommend this course to anyone who wants to start writing smart contracts, learning about blockchain technology.... but also wants to learn Javascript (I am a C# developer so i only know small amounts of JS) and how to utilise the smart contract. I also appreciate Stephen showing us how he lays out his project folder structure.

results.content:
This course is fantastic!!!! It's great for teaching you the fundamentals of Smart contract development! As a PSA 170 minutes of the Appendix and the last module has 300 minutes exclusively about Front End Development. I was able to quickly get up to speed to be able to successfully deploy my own contracts on the Eth main net.  HOWEVER, there are some MAJOR gaps that I had to fill in to go from this course to being able to successfully create and deploy my own D-App. There needs to be another module or a follow up course that does the following.

1.) There needs to be a project where you work with ERC20 tokens & extend the compile.js script from this course to interact with 3rd party smart contract packages.

2.) Cover the truffle CLI and show it automates the process of taking a project from a local dev. env. to a test network then to the Eth. main net. As well as adding 3rd party packages to a truffle project.

3.) Work on a project that highlights the core features of Solidity as a programming language and the Eth. blockchain. Such as events, calling an API from the smart contract and consuming data through oracles,  pushing data from a smart contract to the rest of the internet, and "securing" data that sits publicly on the ETH blockchain.

Overall, this was a great course and I got a lot out of it. Thank you for taking the time to create AMAZING content in a technology where there is little documentation.

results.content:
Great course.

I just finished watching each and every video in this course and here is my take:

0. About 1/3 of the course is devoted to React/Nextjs, which does not help those of us who are working with other front-end javascript frameworks. This time would have been better spent working with more web3 APIs. I, personally, found semantic-ui and next.js a complete waste of time.
2. Very little time was spent on explaining the flow of ether from accounts to transactions
3. I am not sure why we did not talk about setting up a provider on a local PC and connecting to it
4. There was little to no information given about httpprovider which the author used. This provider does not take in a mneomonic like truffle does so, some of us are totally confused about what accounts are used in case of httpprovider and what web.eth.getAccounts() will return. 
5. The course does not have TAs  so, do not expect to get your questions answered.
6. Lastly, I am confused that the author continued to use Metamask when 99.9999% of the users out there do not have that Chrome extension installed. Why didn't we use a more real-world scenario.

Again, despite some of these major shortcomings, the instructor appears knowledgeable and does a really good job of explaining the concepts that he talks about.

I would recommend this course and hope that the instructor at some point will respond to my questions.

results.content:
BE WARNED: The tools and libraries that Stephen uses have since been updated and may not match what he has in his tutorials. If you're not comfortable with looking up documentation and figuring out some things on your own this may not be for you.

Other than that, the course is great. Stephen does a good job breaking things down so that you understand every step of developing a Smart Contract. You even get to learn a lot about React and Next.js, which is a pretty cool bonus I think. The only criticisms I have are that the course ends a bit "anti-climactically," as there's not really a sufficient wrap up, and I also wish there were more "do it yourself" exercises to really nail on the learning aspect. Other than that, I do recommend this course.

results.content:
Basically this guy has proved me wrong. When I heard that I had to use ReactJs (me knowing just basic HTML & CSS) I was afraid that I wouldn't be able to follow. The course took me more than it should however that's because I allocated extra time to learn React (he provides videos for free from another course. This guy is a legend). I feel that this course has explained me very well EVERYTHING. When you learn something, you must "understand it before you understand it". The tutor uses graphs, explanations and everything to make it clear. 
I feel that this course has had a good impact on my life and has opened my eyes. 
I'm looking forward to go again through it whenever I feel the need and buy potential courses from this tutor. 

P.S I also went through a different way by not using react-next just to test my skills with different routing implementation. With online access, support from tutor and own knowledge I managed to do it xD

results.content:
I love the style of Stephen's teaching. Stephen's add on notes to the updated changes and also the inputs from the students of this course are terrific and helped me debug all the problems that I faced during the course by referring to the Q&A of lectures. I didn't run into any issue throughout the course.

Said that Stephen made sure what problem we might run into and how to solve or the 'gotchas' around it. Following along the course was understandable, and I thank him for adding the React part of the class to help build a dApp. 

I would recommend this to everyone to get the fundamental understanding of how to develop smart contracts, test them, deploy them and create a frontend application using react. 

I suggest adding the section on deploying to Heroku. 

I wish Stephen all the best and keep creating such fantastic courses to drive the community forward and help in the mass adoption of blockchain technology.

results.content:
Stephen is an excellent instructor. His expert knowledge of the subject and experience is clearly evident. His approach to teaching Solidity is exactly what I hoped -- i.e. that he avoided having students leaning on Ethereum/Solidity tools that are presently in a constant state of flux because of this evolving technology. I particularly liked the fact Stephen had us create our own Solidity compiler as well as his emphasis on the value of creating Solidity tests.

Before committing to purchase this course, I almost chose not to commit because of Stephen's choice in using React.js for the front-end since I've embraced Vue.js as my Javascript front-end framework of choice. However, I decided the value of learning Solidity to be greater than my reluctance to try React. So before starting the course, I first dove into Stephen's Appendix for "Basic React". I quickly found it somewhat familiar based on my experience with Vue.js. Stephen's approach to introducing React made it surprisingly easy to grasp. I actually gained an appreciation for React.js and Next.js.

However, I'm not sold on the semantic-ui-react CSS framework. It's certainly a feature-rich CSS framework; just seems to heavy for my taste. I still find myself solidly inside the Bulma.io camp.

results.content:
Not worth buying in 2020. Compiler version is much different now, so every lesson from 34 onwards is a 1-hour battle as any IDE I use gives a bunch of unrelated errors (solidity, js, etc). Even if you install 0.4.25 as advised by a tutor, the code is still not working. 
So it is not really possible to go through the course to grasp concepts as wasting too much time to get any code working.
It could be that it is an issue with my PC setup, but in that case the tutor should make few lessons at the beginning dedicated to preparation. I develop with Python, Java, MySQL and some other languages, so can get the code working, but it's just a pain due to old compiler version and other inconsistencies in js and IDE overall.

results.content:
Amazing. I like his style. Because I have taken Stephen's multiple courses and recommend to many of my peers, I would (for this one) state few things that could vastly improve the course:
1. Stephen states rightly that 99.99% of the users do not know or will care to install Metamask. But, this is not really addressed in (say) ... how do we let contributors contribute without Metamask being present. As a corollary -- There is a whole lot of stuff that needs to be covered in Ethereum oriented course that includes account creation, lock/unlock.
2. While there are use cases good for SSR (next.js) ... this is not good for DApp that should not go to any central server. For an app (mobile or otherwise), should be between Ethereum and the app. I think, no DApp (except on time load if browser based) should have to return to any server (beyond EVM) for any ethereum stuff.

Saying this, there in only one other course that is comparable to Stephens when it comes to Ethereum in Udemy. Stephen's expertise in javascript, React, and setting up modules to compile, deploy is outstanding. This is an outstanding course. 

Thank you so much. Looking forward to you giving more advanced courses in the domain in future.
results.content_html:

results.content:
This is an absolutely amazing course - way way way beyond expectations.

I signed up to learn to build an ethereum app, and I learned so much more.

Stephen, you explained many times about your decision to include the React component as if people would hate it, and I just want to say that I appreciated so much that you did the research (rebuilding the app over various tech stacks) and forward-thinking for us to decide to go in this direction.

This course not only covers the low-level coding and syntax of ethereum/solidity development, it also teaches you the high-level considerations on DApp architecture, design and tech-stack decisions.

This is a course that is easy enough to understand for beginners, while in-depth and high-level enough for even senior developers to benefit from.

I am now a big fan of yours, Mr Grider. Thank you for your work.

Funny note: I suspect I'd have a completely misperceived idea of how you sound in real life as I've been listening to you speak at 1.25x speed throughout the course.

results.content:
Many hours invested but very few on Ethereum. I'll update this review when I get past problems with the setup process. The first couple hours of the Ethereum material are excellent but then various runtime setup failures begin. Soon all my time was spent searching the internet for answers, changing machines and even ISPs. The forum tries to help but no luck yet.

Update. After resolving setup challenges the course has some good Ethereum material and the instructor's style is appreciated. Unfortunately the course goes on to fail at signal to noise balance during an end to end example app. Ethereum focus is lost in favor of front end development. A final wrap up that highlights the Ethereum content in the final app would have helped bring this course back to its purpose.

results.content:
+ Great content and learnings. Covering solidity, web3 1.0, React (Vue.JS would have been nicer), etc. 

+ Great coverage of gotchas and things to watch out for

- Instructor tends to repeat themselves a lot and a lot of the videos start and end with > 1 minute repeat of what was shown before. I'd say 20-30% of the content is fluff and could have been trimmed down. 

- Instructor does not answer questions consistently

- I would have liked more discussion on real-world client-server-ethereum architecture. For instance, how do we scale the client when our smart contracts store many thousands of records. Reading directly from the Ethereum network does not scale, so some sort of backend caching layer between the client and the Ethereum network would be needed. Would be nice to show best practices how to build a backend that syncs the events / smart contract contents to a more scalable store.
results.content_html:

results.content:
Very good course. Thumbs up!

I just went in with some basic programming skills (learned PHP 20 years ago, but didn't do any developer stuff over the last 15 years) and I think, this was quite necessary. 

It is also not such a bad thing if you are interested in blockchain technology beyond trading coins, but, however, Stephen teaches you all you need to know regarding how the Blockchain in general and ethereum in particular works. 

Stephen teaches very straight in a good, not to fast pace.
And he is answering questions within just a few days. Thumbs up!

The only thing missing is a script to read. It is a lot of stuff in the course and I would have liked to read the individual steps again in text form. It's a bit tedious to click through the videos whenever you want to look at a small thing. 

The complete code is available and also some graphics, but an extensive script would be nice (for example also to the installation routines for all the required tools and packages or just the single code steps). But that's just a small disadvantage. 

After about 50% of the course I am struggling a bit because it is a lot of stuff and if you don't have good JavaScript knowledge (like me) you'll have to learn a lot more stuff beside the course to understand all the concepts behind deeply. But hey, I want to learn how to code the blockchain. So I have to learn what ever is necessary to reach that goal. But if you are familiar with JavaScript this course should be a peace of cake. 

During the course I developed a much deeper understanding how ethereum Smart Contracts work an I had a lot of ideas for very different business cases. I am sure, at the end of this course, I will have a own working smart contract and the ability to code further DAPP prototypes (while going on in learning from further sources).

In sum, this course is not just for those who want to become a Solidity Developer as also for people who want do get a deeper understanding how this weird smart contracts work and how easy a developer can implement and deploy them (at least in principle). I have learned: Smart Contracts a no rocket science.

results.content:
Really a great course which enables the learner to write not just their own smart contract on the Ethereum blockchain, but also how to test it (manually and automated) and to integrate it into a web application. 

Thus, I fully understand why React was taken into the game and it made sense. But yet, the half point off the maximum rating is because React+SemanticUI took too much place by my perception.  I'd rather had seen some more detail about what to pay attention for on the Solidity side, some examples:
- tips and tricks for saving gas cost on the EVM (e.g. tradeoff between storage and operations)
- what to do and what to avoid in Solidity in comparison to off-chain programming (e.g. how to avoid loops by moving code to originating transactions)
- how data on the blockchain is actually stored and later accessed by the EVM (I really have to research about that)

Maybe topics for an advanced course?

Anyway, overall that was one of the best courses I've ever taken, thanks to Stephen Grider!

results.content:
Good outline of the history and purpose of Ethereum, what an Ethereum network is, and how the blockchain works.

I enjoyed this course because I got to learn how to build Ethereum apps and I also learned about Node.js, React, and other technologies I've never used.

The only thing that was frustrating for me was that the lectures were slow and went into a lot of detail about stuff that I already knew or could understand pretty quickly. I work as a .NET programmer so I have a pretty good knowledge of programming concepts. That was just my experience. Most people probably won't understand a lot of the stuff so I get why the instructor does that.

I would suggest that anyone who has never worked with ES6 javascript syntax go through the section on React before starting any javascript work. Maybe the instructor could add a quick section about the difference between vanilla javascript and ES6 syntax. I was pretty confused about some of the new ES6 syntax at first and I decided to go through the whole course before going over the React section. Once I went over the last section a lot of the confusion was cleared up.

Overall I really enjoyed this course and will look into some more Node.js and React courses to get a better knowledge and understanding of the tools and capabilities of those platforms.

Thank you

results.content:
This is course is my first ethereum course on Udemy. However, I do have quite a few years experience in both Software development and ethereum blockchain development. This course is very good in my opinion and I will rate it a 5. The reason is I did not have to do much tweaking on my own to get the application to work, considering how easily things break with the furiously fast changes happening in the blockchain world. The instructor is very good at explaining things and the pace is good. I cannot speak for novice developers, however I did get stuck a few times where it took me a day or two to figure things out.

Where did I get stuck? 

I had to use solc version 0.6.6
so there are big changes in my code compared to the author's

Second, hurdle with major changes I did was my compile.js file. I did major changes in order to get a stringyfy ABI instead of objects. Without the changes I made, I could not compile neither with ganache nor rinkeby. It took some hard work but it is worth it.

Despite these tremendous changes I still believe this course deserves a 5. In my case as a developer 95% of the material was updated (solc has a new version that works a bit differentely). I hope the author keeps updating this content, this is amazing stuff.

results.content:
Very good instructions, one step at a time.

Would have been better to combine logical sub-topics in one video instead of 5-8 - I find it distracting. At the same time, its good to jump to something specific.

The overall pace could have been a bit faster during the smart contract courses, the instructor spends too much time at times on small points. The pace really picks up later on during the web app building.

Very good by-product was learning React, the approach is methodical. In fact the course lays out a plan how to build a blockchain based app.

Overall, great for learning Ethereum!

Maybe a detail but some other Udemy courses ar just destroyed by someone with good content but poor pronunciation.

results.content: So far so good.  The part about the transaction taking 30 seconds is not clear though.  The blockchain appears to be static because the moment you change any part of the chain you have to update all the subsequent chains because of the hash values being changed.  So does that mean that if a transaction hits a particular block and it gets logged in that particular block (which changes that blocks hash value - requiring rehashing) - does that mean subsequent blocks  in the chain need to be rehashed as well?

results.content:
Fantastic course! The instructor clearly and thoroughly explains everything needed to start working with Ethereum and Solidity. The projects were great examples of real-world applications. Also I greatly appreciated the included tutorials on React, as they helped tremendously with building the front-end for the final project. 

Be warned, there are times you will probably encounter some problems installing the dependencies, but that's only because what is being taught here is so new that development is rapidly changing. But the instructor did update some slides to let you know how to fix some of the most frequent issues.

Ultimately, this course was exactly what I was looking for, and I would highly recommend it to anyone interested in Ethereum and Solidity development.

Fantastic course! The instructor clearly and thoroughly explains everything needed to start working with Ethereum and Solidity. The projects were great examples of real-world applications. Also I greatly appreciated the included tutorials on React, as they helped tremendously with building the front-end for the final project.

Be warned, there are times you will probably encounter some problems installing the dependencies, but that's only because what is being taught here is so new that development is rapidly changing. But the instructor did update some slides to let you know how to fix some of the most frequent issues.

Ultimately, this course was exactly what I was looking for, and I would highly recommend it to anyone interested in Ethereum and Solidity development.

results.content:
Stephen is awesome and I enjoyed taking this course. I had a good familiarity with ethereum and solidity so the real purpose of this course for me was to learn to write some meaningful application using modern web stack. Stephen did a great job at that and I now feel comfortable to hack up websites using React and solidity.

Couple of things that would be helpful:
1. A section that shows how to deploy the contract to mainnet and the web app to some cloud provider.
2. Some best practices on how to upgrade the contract and destroy the old one.

results.content:
Excellent course! Great instructor.

Would have liked to circle back to the contracts and improved some of the enforcement rules such as:
- You should be able to contribute as much as you like, but you still only get one approval vote. 
- Some additional time on contract optimization. 
- Implementing without Metamask, etc.

However, the course is fairly long and it did need to end at some point. Maybe just add a final section that addresses potential problem areas and thoughts for further consideration.

results.content: In brief, the course is well prepared, and in consideration of new updates to package files required for the smooth integration of the ethereum network for the dAPP. It begins by thoroughly explaining what bitcoin and ethereum are, and continues by building on ethereum's context/language, and ends with a fully developed app with a front end. I think overall this deserves 5 stars, and some might disagree, but you can't really beat this kind of program for the price and amount of information you receive.

results.content:
I liked how the course covered the basics of writing Ethereum Smart Contacts in Solidity, along with teaching students the basics for creating Dapps that communicate with a deployed contract.

One issue I have with the course, is the instruction is based on older versions of Solidity and web3. I understand that Blockchain technologies are still in a state of flux, and it would be unreasonable to expect course content to be updated with every change. However, I feel that, I would want to learn more about a new version of these technologies as the capabilities and limitations have changed, sometimes affecting the best practices for working with Smart Contracts.

results.content:
In the time it took me to get to lesson 40 (testing with Mocha) I've already created an ERC20 coin of my own simply modifying existing Solidity code and pushing to MainNet. 

None of that was thanks to this course! 

Here are my problems with this course. 

1.) It says you need basic Javascript/NPM. No, you need very clear understanding of JS. You can get by with basic JS and computer skills just following along, but what did you learn? Get to the Mocha part and tell me any of that makes sense if you're not already a developer. 

We got there too fast, IMO. 

2.) I literally just want to build dApps. I don't care to test things. I want to create an MVP and iterate as I go. I don't want to have to learn React or testing environments, man. I want to see progress and get excited to learn more, then take on that stuff. This is just not getting me there. It reminds me of the Michael Hartl Rails Course where you build something and retain nothing about BDD/TDD or any of the gems because you took on too much at once. 

3.) I feel like if I finish this course I'm going in the wrong direction. 

As an example. I can learn Solidity on CryptoZombies through Loom just the same. You can see your progress visually as it happens (creating zombies!) and while you don't have the benefit of Stephen explaining things (he's good at that) you at least didn't have to do ridiculous testing with frameworks you have zero experience in. 

If I want to build a cryptokitties clone, or similar (which I do) - I can pretty much just take source code and modify it. I was hoping that Stephen's course would enlighten me on the details and how to fully understand the in's and out's - unfortunately, I feel like it would take 1 year at this pace and I'd be stuck taking more courses to get an understanding of the frameworks he's using (JS, Node, React, .etc)

--- 

Ultimately Stephen is a good teacher and I may just be taking the wrong course for my desire. I can't give this 0 stars or 1 star because there's value here. I wish I knew exactly where it was or I'd skip to those sections!
results.content_html:
In the time it took me to get to lesson 40 (testing with Mocha) I've already created an ERC20 coin of my own simply modifying existing Solidity code and pushing to MainNet.

None of that was thanks to this course!

Here are my problems with this course.

1.) It says you need basic Javascript/NPM. No, you need very clear understanding of JS. You can get by with basic JS and computer skills just following along, but what did you learn? Get to the Mocha part and tell me any of that makes sense if you're not already a developer.

We got there too fast, IMO.

2.) I literally just want to build dApps. I don't care to test things. I want to create an MVP and iterate as I go. I don't want to have to learn React or testing environments, man. I want to see progress and get excited to learn more, then take on that stuff. This is just not getting me there. It reminds me of the Michael Hartl Rails Course where you build something and retain nothing about BDD/TDD or any of the gems because you took on too much at once.

3.) I feel like if I finish this course I'm going in the wrong direction.

As an example. I can learn Solidity on CryptoZombies through Loom just the same. You can see your progress visually as it happens (creating zombies!) and while you don't have the benefit of Stephen explaining things (he's good at that) you at least didn't have to do ridiculous testing with frameworks you have zero experience in.

If I want to build a cryptokitties clone, or similar (which I do) - I can pretty much just take source code and modify it. I was hoping that Stephen's course would enlighten me on the details and how to fully understand the in's and out's - unfortunately, I feel like it would take 1 year at this pace and I'd be stuck taking more courses to get an understanding of the frameworks he's using (JS, Node, React, .etc)

---

Ultimately Stephen is a good teacher and I may just be taking the wrong course for my desire. I can't give this 0 stars or 1 star because there's value here. I wish I knew exactly where it was or I'd skip to those sections!

results.content:
Pros and cons of this course:

PROS:
- The course is a great intro to learning how to build smart contracts/dapps on the ethereum network.  
- You learn how to use React to build functioning web interfaces around the smart contracts/dapps.
- Community is active and students help each other out.

CONS:
- Instructor is no longer active and does not reply to students' inquires.
- The code, tools, and versions used for the smart contracts/dapps and node modules are very old.
- Responses from the community takes a very long time.

results.content:
It's a good course. I like Stephen Grider, he's one of the better instructors on UDemy. Always very thorough and I can trust that I'm going to learn a lot from his class. 

The only complaint I have so far is that he's teaching this class as if his target audience is people that are new to software engineering. I don't think new software engineers should start at Blockchain and assume that the majority of people taking this course have at least a year or two of experience. So for example, spending 10+ minutes on the difference between a Web3 constructor and a web3 instance wasn't the best time investment I ever made.

results.content:
Knowledge and experience doesn't equate to the ability to instruct efficiently. However, Stephen is a phenomenal example of an instructor who has the knowledge and the experience as well as the ability to understand learners' psychology. I only had basic Java knowledge when I started the course. 

And now that I am at the end of the course, I feel more comfortable cranking out JS code. I love that he types the code along with us, resists the urge to copy and paste even when there's repetition within a .js file. I believe that this arises from his ability to understand the learning process and from the fact that even if something doesn't make sense the first time you type it, when you type it 5 times, somehow it just sinks in because you can correlate the results of the code with what you typed over and over again.

I also think that this kind of instruction comes from a sense of empathy. He can sense when you are exhausted from writing Mocha tests and he's always on point when he guesses that you are wondering all the "why" questions on doing something a certain way. I felt he was reading my mind throughout the course. Kinda spooky in a good way :) 

Finally, it helps to have instruction presented in a fun way where the instructor can laugh at his trivial mistakes just to make you feel encouraged and less intimated. I love the kickstart application we have built, it pertains to real life and though mine isn't quite working just yet, I believe I have all the knowledge to troubleshoot it. And if I am not able to, that I can turn to the Q&A board where someone will me figure it out.

Thanks you, Stephen, for this comprehensive and detail-oriented course. And I look forward to more courses from you in the future.

results.content:
It's the dictionary meaning of "complete guide". The course teaches you to build real-life applications from scratch. You'll learn both front and back-end programming for Smart Contracts, so it covers end to end application programming.

One of the things I like, the instructor shows a wrong way which probably newbies will think so, then teach the better/correct way, so that you can understand better how to approach a problem. If you encounter any error during the course while you code with the instructor at the same time, just wait 'till the end of the lecture. If you try to find/solve the issues by yourself (like me), you'll waste your time because the instructor shows you common errors and then its resolution purposely as described above.

I wish the instructor add subtitle because auto-subtitles (English) are not correct sometimes.

results.content:
I enjoyed this course a lot and the learning met my expectations. In addition to the solidity part, I was happy to learn more about next.js (which I had previously played with a bit).

I do have one peeve. I did not include it in my rating because it is not part of the promised curriculum. However, it is important: accessibility. The very least we can do for our disabled visitors is to use semantic markup. Things like "Let's use an h3 instead of an h1 because the h1 font is too big" is irresponsible at best. It may even leave us open to litigation as more countries make accessibility mandatory. In this case, if the appropriate semantic tag is h1, use it and live with the default styling, or use it and style it. Using the wrong tag is not an option.

Again, this was not part of the course, but leaders have an obligation to lead. Many students taking this course are inexperienced and if they see Stephen Grider treat accessibility in a cavalier manner, they may think it is OK.

results.content:
The best online course I've ever taken. Learned so much. Eth dapps can be hard to build because of voluminous gotchas and being such a new field, a shortage of docs. Dr. Grider will really show you the fundamentals and give you a solid working knowledge.

Coincidentally, my company started a blockchain project a few months after I took this course. I was able to use my newfound skills to lead our dapp development and pull off some stuff I never would've been able to without this course.

The solidity/eth space changes quickly; there are a few things in this course I can think of that might be dated now - but even so, it is entirely worth it. Thanks Stephen!!

results.content:
Très bonne formation sur les bases de Solidity et de son intégration dans une application concrète. 
Les points positifs:
- Les projets sont concret et de difficulté croissants. 
- Stephen n'hésite pas à refaire un résumé rapide à chaque début de vidéo sur ce qu'on a mit en place lors de la précédente vidéo afin de ne pas perdre le fil.
- Afin de foncer tête baissé dans le code, Stephen prend le temps de faire des schémas pour expliquer la logique, la structure, l'organisation, vers quoi on va, etc.
- Introduction à React.js compris dans la formation solidity
- Explication de chaque ligne de code/fonction

Les points d'améliorations:
- J'aurais bien voulu aller un peu plus loin dans Solidity (standard erc-20 et autres, un projet sur créer une ICO, l'utilisation d'API avec Ethereum/Solidity)
- J'aurais également souhaité comprendre ce qu'est NextJs et qu'elles sont les autres techno similaires. Je sais que le cours est sur Solidity mais l'explication "on prends NextJs car j'ai réalisé ce projet avec d'autres technos et c'est le plus simple", je trouve ça léger surtout que je ne connaissait pas React et son environnent (sachant que les autres cours de stephen ne font pas référence à NextJs)
- Une mise à jour avec la dernière version de Solidity

results.content:
this must have been amazing back when it was made in like 2017. very outdated now. still good as intro, but must supplement your own troubleshooting to learn what changed.

this course uses solidity version 0.4.17. we are currently two major versions ahead on 0.6.8 as of may 2020. the introductory sections are still probably good, but the actual solidity code needs to be refactored to accommodate changes in the language, but is not bad. the concepts discussed lay a good foundation for how to work with this tech if you've never used it before. this would be a good supplement, but i cant recommend it as a comprehensive overview to new people without reservation since this really benefits new people, but new people might not be capable of knowing what's outdated and what's not. since 3 years ago, there are a lot more resources available online to achieve similar levels of introduction, but i like stephen's teaching style, so if you're deep into his way of teaching react, and happen to want to learn how to integrate web3js (this course does not cover ethersjs, which has overtaken web3js in some dev communities).

Stephen is very experienced and knowledgeable.
The first two parts of the course was great, but later on Next.js was introduced, wich actually added some complexity.  Also, the application became very sluggish and slow, adding to the slowness of the blockchain transactions.  Maybe he should just have used Create React App.

Also, it would been better if he went further explaining how to control Metamask panels and accounts swiching in relation to the UI.

Overall, however, it was a great course.  Thank you.

The first two parts of the course was great, but later on Next.js was introduced, wich actually added some complexity. Also, the application became very sluggish and slow, adding to the slowness of the blockchain transactions. Maybe he should just have used Create React App.

Also, it would been better if he went further explaining how to control Metamask panels and accounts swiching in relation to the UI.

Overall, however, it was a great course. Thank you.

results.content:
first 2 part is good, easy to follow, but still very slow,  by slow i meant really very very slow. everyone have at least a year of programming experience will feel like that. if you just learn how to write javascript how to write a test is good, because stephen explained it very well in details which he is very good at. it's obviously he is a master of javascript and associated framework as well. for that reason, he never covered other thing beyond javascript.  he just picked some knowledge of ethereum and tried to put it with javascript together. there are much more stuffs about blockchain and solidity need to be covered if you claimed it is a complete course. by the way  i guess many people choose this course is because it is long enough with 24 hours video explaination which is fair enough as what a so-called complete developer guide need to be . I personally feel like it only covered 30% of concepts we need to know. but it 's still a good start i probably gonna recommend to some others as well. you do learn how to build a full app with ethereum and solidity, but if you wanna build your own chain and generate some money is not enough at all.
at first i wathed the video at 1.25 times speed, and then speed up tp 1.5 times, and finally 2 times, amazing!!! right? I am not a english native speaker, but after i checked the title of every video I know what is gonna talked in this course. and his accent is good and easy to follow. so 2 times speed is still able to follow.

by the way, I checked the other course which made my stephen, all of them are super long.  people put that much of time to finish the course but get little back is always not a good thing.

results.content: If you're new to Ethereum programming, this is a fantastic course.  The instructor makes no assumptions about your knowledge of Node, JavaScript, and other related topics.  They also do a very good job in handling difficult issues that can arise when programming with new technologies (i.e., versions, and feature changes).

results.content: The lessons and clear and it's at a good pace. It's exactly at my level having no prior Ethereum exposure but having lots of prior development experience. results.content:
The course is very good. It is good structured with nice examples.
At the end you will know a lot about blockchain, Ethereum and solidity.
A basic programming prerequisite is required. Someone that is complete beginner will have difficulties understating topics presented.
This course represents the best investment for anyone interested in the subject!

results.content: Course is very outdated, unfortunately Solidity is evolving pretty quick. What is more introduction to React is from 2015... Frontend technologies are evolving fast as well :) Instructor could attach notes with package.json and versions of libraries that he used in the course - it would be very helpful as it's not obvious when he is just installing recent versions of libraries which are very outdated now. On the other hand - Stephen did great job creating this course as it covers many aspects of Solidity, Dapps and dependent technologies. I hope he'll update it some day and  introduce some new cool stuff. Thanks and good luck!
results.content_html: Course is very outdated, unfortunately Solidity is evolving pretty quick. What is more introduction to React is from 2015... It is also very easy to listen to and despite the length, I don't get bored or frustrated at all. Its fascinating.  So I thank you for this great course!
